Graphical abstract The kinetics of the partial oxidation (POX) reforming of diesel was studied using hexadecane as a surrogate for diesel. The kinetic experimental data used were obtained over a 5wt%Ni/Ce0.5Zr0.33Ca0.085Y0.085(5N/CZCaY) catalyst at atmospheric pressure and temperatures of 1123–1223 K in a packed bed reactor. The kinetic model that best described the experimental rates was developed based on the Eley-Rideal (ER) formulation assuming the dissociative adsorption of diesel (hexadecane) on the catalyst active site as the rate determining step. Also, a rate law based reactor model was developed and the resulting partial differential equations solved using finite elements method. A satisfactory agreement between the model prediction and experimental results was obtained which showed that the predicted concentration and temperature profiles for the process justify the assumption of plug flow and isothermal behaviour in the radial direction. mixture, Pa s μi,j Vapor viscosity of pure component i or j at the temperature Ø Porosity ρb Bulk density of catalyst bed given by (1-Ø)ρc ρc Pellet density 1 Introduction Energy consumption has increased drastically over the past few decades. The transportation and electricity sectors consume a greater share of this energy, which is derived from fossil fuels typically hydrocarbons such as coal, natural gas & crude oil. This has led to a corresponding increase in the emission of pollutants that pose health risks to humans, deplete the ozone layer and have other negative ecological effects. In the past decade, the transportation sector alone has consumed 25% of the world's energy and produced 22% of its CO2 emissions [1]. As a result, renewable/clean sources of energy have paved the way for research and development towards a sustainable future. Hydrogen, the most abundant element on earth, constituting 75% of the planet's elemental mass yet does not exist in its elemental form [2], is one of the alternative sources of energy with negligible emission when used as fuel, as the product of its combustion is water vapour. It is mainly produced either from the electrolysis of water or from the reforming of hydrocarbon and is mainly utilized in fuel cell powered vehicles. However, the main obstacle that prevents the use of hydrogen as a fuel currently is the lack of infrastructure and efficient storage technologies [3]. On-board hydrogen production from a suitable liquid source seems to be a more practical short-medium term perspective. Hydrocarbon fuels like kerosene, gasoline, jet fuel and diesel are favoured as the most suitable hydrogen carriers because they are easily transportable and have an existing infrastructure for distribution [4]. However the problem associated with heavy fuels processing is the ease of carbon deposition and soot emission, high temperature at fuel reforming and high energy consumption for fuel evaporation [5]. In this study, the production of hydrogen from diesel fuel is particularly of interest as the key benefits of diesel fuel are its existing worldwide infrastructure, high energy content (about 10 kWh/L), easy handling and the prospect of biomass derived, and therefore carbon neutral biodiesel [6]. This prospect could provide a smooth transition from fossil to renewable feedstock [7]. Partial oxidation (POX) is one of the viable technologies for hydrogen production from diesel fuels which involves the combustion of the fuel at high temperatures in a limited supply of oxygen. POX offers the advantage of lower energy consumption, requires a compact sized reactor to operate and thus suits the on-board application of fuel cells. The challenges however faced with the partial oxidation reforming of liquid fuels is the complex nature of the fuel, the presence of coke precursors that could cause catalyst deactivation, high energy density of the fuel which leads to high temperatures and difficulty in ensuring a homogenous mixture of air and fuel to control combustion and formation of hot spots [4]. With respect to the complex nature of diesel, hexadecane C16H34 is often used as a diesel fuel surrogate as it is the dominant hydrocarbon in certified grade diesel fuel with a composition of about 38.7 wt% [1]. C16H34 + 8O2 ⇔ 16CO + 17H2 ΔH = −1319 kJ/mol On the other hand, the development of carbon resistant catalysts that can withstand deactivation for an extended period of time is required. In line with this, several catalysts have been used in the study of POX of heavy hydrocarbons including pyrochlores [8] and hexa-aluminates [9]. The use of precious metals like Pt, Pd and Rh on oxide supports such as CeO2, La2O3, and ZrO2 with superior activity and stability have also been reported [10]. Generally, catalysts used for reforming are Ni based because of its lower cost and supported mostly on Al2O3, MgO, or other ceramic supports. However, nickel based catalysts are prone to deactivation by coking [11], therefore the development of a robust nickel-based catalyst is important. Innovative support materials, improved Ni dispersion, and use of promoters have been applied to prevent carbon deposition [12], therefore in this study, a quartenary nickel based catalyst containing two metal promoters (Ca and Y) in addition to ceria-zirconia oxide support which yield good nickel dispersion [13], has been used. Mixture homogeneity is a crucial factor in the design of a reformer, which in turn is dependent on the reaction kinetics, however the kinetics of the partial oxidation reforming of diesel fuels is not widely reported as compared to those of light hydrocarbon fuels like methane [1]. It is therefore pertinent to have an insight into the kinetics of the diesel POX reaction and what takes place in the catalytic packed bed reactor so as to make better predictions that could optimize the performance of the system. 2 Theory 2.1 Kinetic modeling Developing a kinetic model requires a good expression of the elementary steps that lead from the feed materials to products. Few reports are available in the literature on the mechanism of this process and have been developed on the basis of the reaction mechanisms and kinetic parameters of the smaller hydrocarbons [14]. The kinetics of hexadecane steam reforming was studied by Patel et al. [1] in which they compared a Power Law model, an Eley–Rideal model, and a Langmuir–Hinshelwood model and estimated the kinetic parameters from experiments in a micro reactor coated with Rh/Al2O3 catalyst. While the Langmuir–Hinshelwood model failed mechanistically, and the Power Law model failed to predict the results at high S/C ratios, the Eley–Rideal model reproduced the experimentally measured reaction rates for a wide range of concentrations and temperatures. Thormann et al. [7] also developed a kinetic model and reported an order of 0.5 with respect to hexadecane and activation energy of 71 kJ/mol in their study of the steam reforming of hexadecane over Rh/CeO2 catalyst. Furthermore, Gawade et al. [1] studied the kinetics of the steam reforming of n-hexadecane and used the first order kinetics power law model, Mars-Van Krevelen model and Eley-Rideal model to fit the experimental data on hexadecane combustion while they used Langmuir Hinshelwood bimolecular model and a Langmuir Hinshelwood dual site model for steam reforming of hexadecane. Consequently, either of the two models did not fit the hexadecane steam reforming reaction mechanism appropriately and the Eley-Rideal model gave a good fit. Other authors have also contributed to the kinetic study of the reforming of diesel [14–16]. Nevertheless, due to the wide variety of catalysts used in the POX reactions carried out by the different authors in literature, it was yet difficult to reach a consensus on a kinetic model for the POX process. Therefore, this study presents a mechanistic kinetic model development of the POX reaction for the experimental data produced by our research group in a previous work [13]. Hexadecane was used as a surrogate for diesel for simplicity and because of its higher concentration compared to other components present in the complex diesel mixture. Empirical power law model and mechanistic rate models were proposed to fit the experimental data. First the power law rate model was developed as shown; − r A = k 0 e ( − E / R T ) N A m Afterwards, several mechanistic models were developed based on Langmuir–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson (LHHW) and ER mechanisms. Basically, LHHW differs from the ER mechanism as the LHHW formulation requires the adsorption of the two reactant species on the catalyst active site for any reaction to take place whereas the ER formulation requires only one of the two reactants species to adsorb with the other reacting specie assumed to be in the gaseous phase [17]. The mechanistic kinetic models were developed by considering each of the elementary reactions steps given below as the rate determining step, except in the third mechanism. The elementary reactions assumed to have taken place in the process based on ER mechanism are given below: a) Dissociative Adsorption of C16H34 on catalyst surface to yield alkyl intermediates C16H34 + 16* ⇔ 14CH2* + 2CH3* b) Surface reaction of intermediates with oxygen in gas phase 14CH2* + 7O2 ⇔ 14CO↑ + 14H2* 2CH3* + O2 ⇔ 2CO↑ + 3H2↑ + 2* 1. Desorption of intermediate from catalyst surface 14H2* ⇔ 14H2↑ + 14* Similarly, the following elementary steps were used in developing models based on LHHW mechanism: a) Molecular Adsorption of C16H34 on catalyst surface to yield an intermediate C16H34 + * ⇔ C16H34* b) Dissociative adsorption of oxygen molecule on catalyst active site 8O2 + 16* ⇔ 8O* + 8O* c) Surface reaction of adsorbed oxygen and adsorbed C16H34* C16H34* + 8O* ⇔ 17H2↑ + 8C2O* + * d) Surface reaction between intermediates 8C2O* + 8O* ⇔ 16 CO* e) Desorption of intermediate from catalyst surface 16CO* ⇔ 16CO↑ + 16* A third LHHW mechanism was also proposed as follows; a) Dissociative Adsorption of C16H34 on catalyst surface to yield alkyl intermediates C16H34 + 16* ⇔ 14CH2* + 2CH3* b) Molecular adsorption of oxygen molecule on catalyst active site 8O2 + 8* ⇔ 8O2* c) Surface reaction of adsorbed oxygen and alkyl intermediate 2CH3* + O2* ⇔ 2CO↑ + 3H2↑ + 3* d) Surface reaction between intermediates 14CH2* + 7O2* ⇔ 14 CO* + 14H2 ↑ + 7* e) Desorption of intermediate from catalyst surface 14CO* ⇔ 14CO ↑ + 14* In this third mechanism, only the first elementary step was considered as rate determining step. The sum of six LHHW and four ER models were formulated and tested. All the rate models, and the assumptions used in their derivation are given in Table 1 . The selection of the plausible models was based on a statistical method (i.e., the average absolute deviation (AAD%)) between predicted and experimental results as well as the relationship between the activation energy value and that obtained from the power law model. 2.2 Numerical modeling The performance of the packed bed reactor was simulated using a computational fluid dynamics software (COMSOL multyphysics) which applies the finite elements method to solve the partial differential equations for mass and energy balances. Momentum balance was not considered here because the pressure drop across the reactor was assumed to be negligible. Fig. 1 shows the reactor geometry for the model equations for each of the component species i and can be expressed in the radial and axial directions in cylindrical coordinates (Eqs. 1–5). (6) below: (6) D eff [ ∂ 2 N i ∂ r 2 + 1 r ∂ N i ∂ r ] + D eff ∂ 2 C i ∂ z 2 + ρ B v A ( − r i ) = v ∂ N i ∂ z The parameters used in the simulation are given in Table 2 . 3 Experimental details 3.1 Catalyst and feed material A ceria-based mixed oxide catalyst of nominal composition 5wt%Ni/Ce0.5Zr0.33Ca0.085Y0.085 was employed in the current study, and it is abbreviated as 5N/CZCaY. The selection of 5N/CZCaY catalyst for this study was the result of a screening study taking n-Hexadacane as a surrogate for SD by our group [19] (Idem et al., 2010). Cerium (Ce) and zirconium (Zr) combinations have drawn much attention recently, as they could improve textural properties, enhance activity, improve active metal dispersion, eliminate or reduce coke formation, and prevent thermal sintering when used as support material in catalyst [19] (Ibrahim and Idem, 2008). Here, CaO and Y2O3 were added as promoters for the catalyst [19] (Idem et al., 2010). The 5% nickel loading was selected on the basis of Ibrahim and Idem’s (2008) [19] studies on a similar hydrocarbon feed (i.e. gasoline), where they have shown that lower nickel loadings, typically 3–5 wt%, exhibit better degrees of dispersion and high levels of stable conversion and selectivity. An earlier publication from our group concluded that surfactant-assisted method yields better catalyst than the conventional co-precipitation method, and a higher surfactant/metal ratio is desirable for better stability [20]. In accordance with the above reference, the CZCaY support was prepared by surfactant assisted method, a surfactant/metal ratio of 1.25 was found to be optimum. The main reactants of catalytic partial oxidation of synthetic diesel (SD) are SD and oxygen (O2). Synthetic diesel fuel is not a commercial grade diesel. Commercial diesel fuel consists of approximately 75 vol.% saturated hydrocarbons and 25 vol.% aromatic hydrocarbons, with an average chemical formula ranging approximately from C10H20 to C15H28 [21]. In our lab, we mixed various compounds that are predominantly found in commercial diesel to prepare a synthetic diesel (SD) mixture while maintaining the above-mentioned saturated and aromatic hydrocarbon percentages. The individual components were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (Canada) and had purity higher than 99.0%. Table 3 below shows the composition of the synthetic diesel feed. 3.2 Experimental procedure A fixed catalyst particle size (0.8 mm) was used and isothermal conditions were maintained for all the experimental runs. A fixed amount of α-Al2O3 (7.6 g) of the same particle size as the catalyst (0.8 mm) was used as a diluent for all the experimental runs. Experimental runs to collect intrinsic kinetic data for POX of SD were performed in a tubular fixed-bed reactor, as shown in Fig. 2 . The reactor (ID = 12.7 mm and length ≈ 550 mm), made of Inconel 625 high temperature alloy, was housed vertically in an electric tubular furnace (Zesta Engineering Ltd.) and was controlled by a programmable temperature controller (Zesta). All the gases were regulated through pre-calibrated mass (gas) flow controllers with digital readout units (Aalborg Instruments). SD was fed by means of a syringe pump (KD scientific). The catalyst bed temperature was recorded and controlled by sliding a k-type thermocouple into the center of the catalyst bed. In a typical experiment, a known amount (100, 150, 200, and 250 mg) of 0.8 mm-sized catalyst particles were mixed with 7.6 g of 0.8 mm-sized α-Al2O3 to obtain a catalyst bed height of ∼4.5 cm. Prior to each run, the catalyst was activated in situ by reducing it at 700 °C for 2 h using a gas mixture of 5 vol.% H2 in N2 (flow rate = 100 sccm). Air (avg. 21% O2 bal. N2) was fed at a calculated flow rate in order to obtain the desired O2/SD ratio (6.7, 8.0, 9.3, and 10.5). The kinetic experiments were performed at three different temperatures, namely 1123, 1173, and 1223 K. After attaining steady state at the designated temperature, the reformate gas samples were analyzed at regular intervals of 20–30 min. The product reformate stream coming from the reactor was passed through a water-cooled condenser and then passed through an ice-cold knockout trap to separate permanent gases from condensate (mainly water). The composition of the product gas was monitored by an online gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (GC-TCD) (HP 6890, Agilent Technologies) using the molecular sieve and Haysep columns (Alltech Associates), with helium as the carrier gas. Some tests were repeated in order to check for reproducibility. The maximum error in the SD conversion and H2 selectivity data was <1%. 3.3 Kinetic data collection In order to collect kinetic data from the experimental runs, three parameters were varied: temperature (T), feed ratio (O2/SD), and weight-time (W/FSD,0), that is temperature (1123, 1173 and 1223 K), O2/SD feed ratio (6.7, 8.0,9.3, and 10.5) and W/FSD,0 (19,008, 28,512, 38,052, and 47,556 kgcatalyst*s/kmolSD). Prior to selecting the above stated conditions, preliminary experiments and some theoretical calculations were performed to obtain the regime of operating conditions that will ensure intrinsic kinetic data collection so as to eliminate film and molecular diffusion as reported by [22]. In addition, in order to ensure plug flow conditions (i.e., zero radial velocity and temperature profile), absence of back mixing, and absence of channeling, certain criteria reported by Froment and Bischoff [23] were implemented. These criteria include that the ratio of catalyst bed height to catalyst particle size (Lr/dp) be equal or less than 50, and that the ratio of internal diameter of the reactor to the catalyst particle size (d/dp) be equal or less than 10. In this work, we used Lr/dp and d/dp of 56.2 and 15.9 respectively, which met all the requirements for plug flow. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Heat and mass transport limitations In the kinetic study of any reaction, data collection can only be considered intrinsic in the absence of heat and mass transfer resistance. In this section, the interparticle and intraparticle mass and heat transfer resistances and the effects on the rate of the reaction was investigated at 1223 K which is the highest temperature used for the partial oxidation reforming of diesel. 4.1.1 Heat transport effects According to the Prater analysis, the internal pore heat transfer resistance could be evaluated using certain correlations as reported in literature [19] using the Eq. The values obtained for the parameters of the kinetic models that converged as well as that of the power law are presented in Table 5 . The validation of the models was based on the determination of the percentage average absolute deviation (AAD%) between the predicted rate using proposed kinetic model and the experimentally observed rate. Out of the 10 models, only five converged and were initially short-listed. They were however subjected to further thermodynamic scrutiny based on Boudart Mears Vannice (BMV) guidelines [31], and with activation energy comparable to that of the power law model. From the AAD% computations and the parity plot, the models with the least AAD are models 1, 5 and 10 having similar AAD of 8.52%, this is also reflected in Fig. 5 were all 3 models overlap. The three models also resulted in values of activation energy closest to that of the power law model than models 3 and 4. In addition, the variation of the adsorption constant with temperature should be inverse, that is, higher temperature should result in lower K values in line with Van't Hoff equation, otherwise the model is not a good fit and the mechanism implied is irreversible (non-equilibrium) or multi-step rate controls. The development of the skeletal models described in the kinetic modeling section was mainly based on general guidelines from previous similar studies [19,31] using LHHW and ER formulations. Also experimental observations were used to develop the model steps for instance, the positive role of increasing O2/SD ratio on the reaction rate indicates that oxygen molecules are either reacting in the gas phase or are adsorbed on surfaces different than the those occupied with hexadecane. Furthermore, the dissociative adsorption of the hydrocarbon (hexadecane in this case) on the catalyst surface is inevitable, due to the fact that Ni-based catalyst are highly active in CC bond scission reactions [3]. To avoid complexities in the parameters estimation, the formation of wide range of intermediates was not explicitly taken into consideration. Inclusion of such intermediates will improve the predictability of the models at the expense of computational time, hence the developed models are reasonably simple without influencing the integrity of the reaction mechanism [31]. From the results as given in Table 6 , Model 1 can be said to satisfy the BMV rules because its adsorption constants, KA and KB, decrease with temperature increase and the absolute value of entropy is greater than 10 and less than 12.2 − 0.0014ΔH. In addition, the absolute values of entropy is less than SG for hexadecane which is 586.2 J/K mol and 205 J/K mol for oxygen. Rule 1: ΔS < 0 Rule 2: | Δ S | < S G Rule 3: | − Δ S | > 10 e n t r o p y u n i t s Rule 4: | − Δ S | < 12.2 − 0.0014 Δ H In summary, 0 < −ΔS <SG and 10 < −ΔS < [12.2–0.0014ΔH]. Thus, model 1 which results from the Eley Rideal mechanism and assumes the dissociative adsorption of hexadecane as the rate determining step, can be said to be the best fit next to the power law model. This is in accordance with similar works in literature. Thormann et al. [7] reported the dissociative adsorption of hexadecane using LHHW mechanism as a good fit for steam reforming of hexadecane. Gawade et al. [1] also found the ER model to be a good fit and satisfied the thermodynamic criteria. The values of activation energy obtained from the power law model and model 1 are approximately 12 KJ/mol and 8 KJ/mol respectively which is in line with the trend reported by Praharso et al. [31] revealing that the activation energy of higher hydrocarbon reforming decreases with higher carbon atoms. Based on the above, the following rate equation (Eq. (18)) can be deduced: (18) − r A = 7.3 × 10 3 e − ( 8.4 × 10 3 ) / R T [ C A − C C 16 C D 17 C B 8 K P ] [ 1 + 4.02 × 10 3 C D + C C C D 1.5 C B + C C C D C B ] 16 4.3 Predictive performance of the numerical model The aim of any simulation is to obtain a mathematical model that describes what goes on the reactor within a range of operating conditions with minimal error. The model was used to predict diesel conversion at different temperatures and W/FA0 used in the experimental studies to validate the proposed model. Fig. 6 shows the decrease in the CO concentration with respect to the reactor length due to the continuous oxidation of the SD toward hydrogen. A similar observation was reported for the reduction of CO yield with time on stream for the catalytic POX using Ru-substituted pyrochlore [8]. 4.4 Effect of axial dispersion term Several arguments have ensued as to whether the axial dispersion term in the transport balance equations has any significant contribution to the performance in a packed bed reactor model at certain reactor dimensions. For instance, Carberry et al. [32] recommended that if the ratio of catalyst bed length to catalyst particle diameter is greater than 100, then, the axial dispersion term could be ignored. Also Froment and Bischoff [23] recommended that the axial dispersion term is insignificant when the catalyst bed height exceeds the particle diameter by 50. However previous literature [18,33] showed from simulation studies that these criteria do not always hold, and should be further studied in any particular case before it is applied in developing a model. Even though when these criteria are employed, they predicted an approximate plug flow behavior (i.e., almost flat temperature profile), the radial variation in temperature can be very prominent in an industrial scale reactor, as was shown by [12,18]. Aboudheir et al. [12,18] stated that the axial mixing term enhances the conversion of the reactants to product by maintaining a high reaction temperature simultaneous with the promotion of mixing of the reactants as they proceed along the bed which brings them into good contact thereby leading to increased conversion. In a similar way, the axial mixing term in the energy balance equation is a heat transfer term. Therefore, the exclusion of this term would mean neglecting a significant enhancement in heat transfer in the process. An enhanced rate of heat transfer as the fluid travels down the bed provides the heat thereby maintaining the high temperature necessary for the conversion of the reactant species to product. The rapid heat transfer also helps to maintain the heat along the reactor length thereby avoiding a sharp drop that could occur caused by an increase in conversion promoted by axial mixing. Basically, the axial dispersion term comprises a thermal conductivity term and a gradient term. The former is always positive whereas the later could be positive or negative depending on the nature of the reaction. In an exothermic reaction as it is in our case, the temperature gradient is positive and this makes the term behave opposite to the other terms on the right hand side and therefore a heat absorption term rather than a heat contributing term. This term is a second differential term implying that it makes minimal contribution. However, when combined with the multiplier in the equation (i.e., the effective thermal conductivity), the contribution could be significant. The amount of heat contributed largely depends on the value of the effective thermal conductivity. For a system with high effective thermal conductivity, the heat transfer rate is high. This helps maintain the process temperature even though the reaction is producing heat as it proceeds along the length of the reactor. Also, the degree of under prediction is a function of the steepness of the axial temperature profile. This shows that even when these well documented criteria have been met by the experimental conditions, the axial dispersion term should only be disregarded after a careful comparison between the results obtained with and without its inclusion in the model equation have been made (Fig. 7 ). 4.5 Simulation of the axial temperature profile Fig. 8 shows the axial temperature profile. This figure shows the occurrence of a rapid rise in temperature from the feed entrance at the top of the catalyst bed to a bed depth of about 45 mm after which it slows down and finally levels off towards the exit of the catalyst bed. This is a reflection of the slowing down of the conversion of the feed as it travels down the catalyst bed resulting from the reduction in the concentration of the reactant species. Fig. 9 gives the effect of temperature on the conversion of diesel. As can be seen from the graph, increasing the temperature of the inlet stream between 1123 and 1223 K reduces the conversion. Although this is contrary to the experimental observation in which higher temperature increases conversion. However considering the fact that the reaction is exothermic, according to the reaction thermodynamics, increasing the temperature should reduce the conversion as observed in the both figures below. The essence of any simulation is to give valid prediction of a system. As such, the model developed was validated with experimental data at different temperatures and W/FA0. This has been discussed in previous sections. 4.6 Simulation of effect of reactor length and W/NA0 To reduce the additional cost that would be incurred in separating the unconverted reactants from the products, it is essential to design a reactor that will give high conversion of reactants. This can be achieved by either increasing the catalyst bed length or by increasing W/NA 0, both resulting in a decrease in space velocity of the reacting species in the PBTR. The effect of increasing the catalyst bed length from 4.5 cm to 20 cm on the conversion was investigated. From results in Fig. 10 , it can be seen that increasing the bed length increased the conversion of the reactant. However the increase in conversion is rather gradual as compared to the initial sharp increase in conversion experienced over the first 5 cm of the bed up to about 85%. This shows that the cost of removal of unreacted reactant can be minimized by increasing the catalyst bed height, but to reasonable height of say 10 cm as seen in the graph. Furthermore the effect of flow rate (at constant temperature of 1123 K) on the reaction kinetics was investigated with the simulation and validated using experimental results. As can be seen from Fig. 11 , reducing the flow rate increases the W/FA0-weight time and increases the conversion of the reactant. This is in line with the experimental data. This shows a potential reduction in cost incurred in separating unconverted reactants from products by maintaining low feed flow rates and low temperature in order to optimize conversion of reactant. 5 Conclusion In this study, 3 mechanisms were proposed based on the Langmuir Hinshelwood and Eley Rideal mechanisms and 10 kinetic models were formulated. Out of the 10 models, only 3 models yielded minimal average absolute deviation of 8.52%. These models were further scrutinized using the Boudart-Mears-Vannice guidelines. Only 1 model based on the dissociative adsorption of diesel (hexadecane) on the catalyst surface and following the Eley Rideal formulation successfully passed through the thermodynamic scrutiny. The power law model was also tested amongst others and resulted in activation energy of 12.4 KJ/mol and order of reaction equal to 1, with respect to hexadecane (diesel). This is close to the value of 16 KJ/mol obtained experimentally [13]. A numerical model was used to simulate the packed bed reactor at the operating conditions and validated with experimental data. The simulation yielded valid results as compared to the experimental data in terms of conversion. Further predictive tests were also simulated to predict the performance of the reactor by varying the operating conditions. It was observed that the cost of separating unconverted reactants from the product can be reduced by operating at lower temperatures and lower flow rates, as these yield higher conversions. coredata.dc:description: The kinetics of the partial oxidation (POX) reforming of diesel was studied using hexadecane as a surrogate for diesel. The kinetic experimental data used were obtained over a 5wt%Ni/Ce0.5Zr0.33Ca0.085Y0.085(5N/CZCaY) catalyst at atmospheric pressure and temperatures of 1123–1223 K in a packed bed reactor. The kinetic model that best described the experimental rates was developed based on the Eley-Rideal (ER) formulation assuming the dissociative adsorption of diesel (hexadecane) on the catalyst active site as the rate determining step. Also, a rate law based reactor model was developed and the resulting partial differential equations solved using finite elements method. A satisfactory agreement between the model prediction and experimental results was obtained which showed that the predicted concentration and temperature profiles for the process justify the assumption of plug flow and isothermal behaviour in the radial direction.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic kinetics and reactor modelling of hydrogen production from the partial oxidation of diesel over a quartenary metal oxide catalyst
